user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.
A pointer should not point to a const-qualified type if the pointer is used by a function that modifies the object pointed to by the pointer.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified send_bad_request code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/499.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of send_bad_request as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_bad_request:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
send_bad_request (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  struct MHD_Response *res;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  res =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (BAD_REQUEST_PAGE),
                                            (const void *) BAD_REQUEST_PAGE);
  ret = MHD_queue_response (con, MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST, res);
  MHD_destroy_response (res);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function send_bad_request:
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (size_t size,
                                        const void *buffer)
{
  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                                 buffer,
                                                                 NULL,
                                                                 NULL);
}
...
#define BAD_REQUEST_PAGE "<html>\n""<head>\n""<title>WebSocket chat</title>\n""</head>\n""<body>\n""Bad Request\n""</body>\n""</html>\n"
</additional code>
Judge whether the above send_bad_request code violates the rule 8.13 or not.
scenario: In the send_bad_request function, the pointer passed to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static is a const void* pointing to BAD_REQUEST_PAGE, which is a const-qualified string literal. Since the function and underlying functions do not modify the pointed data, this usage complies with Rule 8.13. No pointer is used in a context that attempts to modify a const-qualified object.
